Subjective: Spot on neck for ~2 weeks. Started as small wound after shaving, possibly also an insect bite. Initially thought it was a wart. Now swollen and redder. Itches. Intermittent scabbing, scab falls off and reforms. No pain. No other similar spots on body. PMH: Warts, ear abscess (removed). FH: Paternal grandfather and uncles with sun-related skin problems on head (type unknown). Social: Not mentioned. ICE: Worried about skin cancer after online search (Google Lens/AI). Request: Wants lesion identified and removed; prefers freezing if an option.
Objective: Skin: Single, raised, pinkish-red lesion on neck, approx. 0.5 cm. Redder spot in the center. No visible scab or flaking on exam. Remainder of neck skin shows some freckles, no other suspicious lesions. Dermoscopy performed. Lymph: No cervical lymphadenopathy.
Assessment: Uncertain skin lesion, neck. Differential diagnosis includes pyogenic granuloma vs. atypical mole. Awaiting dermatology opinion.
Plan: Plan teledermatology e-consultation; will send photo to dermatologist for assessment.
Discussed potential removal options: cryotherapy (freezing), excision, or curettage with histology. Patient expressed preference for cryotherapy.
Follow-up: Will call patient this Friday (before 10 AM or after 3 PM) with dermatologist's advice. Patient gave permission to leave voicemail if unreachable.
Patient mentioned separate issue of knee pain after running; advised to schedule a new appointment to address this.
